snippet: Under the terms of a settlement in a lawsuit over payment processing, merchants can charge higher prices to customers who pay with credit cards.
abstract: MasterCard, Visa and several major banks agree to pay more than $6 billion to settle accusations that they engaged in anticompetitive practices in payment processing; settlement is the culmination of a lawsuit brought in federal court on behalf of roughly seven million merchants in 2005; retailers will now be able to charge their customers more for paying with credit cards.
lead_paragraph: Under the terms of a settlement in a lawsuit over payment processing, merchants can charge higher prices to customers who pay with credit cards.

headline.main: MasterCard and Visa Will Pay Billions to Settle Antitrust Suit
headline.print_headline: MasterCard And Visa Settle Claims Of Antitrust
